content: I've removed the tag DLX since it's covered by Algorithm X.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A good opportunity to finally implement my version of Algorithm X using dancing links.
Still was challenging to get pass the time limit, probably because I implemented the links as indexes in a not-sparse matrix to simplify things, but I suppose the really big size was an issue (initially, the bulk of the time was spent building the matrix, not actually solving).
good job

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Re-Approving

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Re-Approving

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
I like the idea of this puzzle even if it seems hard :)
a good challenge, it really needs to be validated quickly after having corrected it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This was a tough challenge, like  Timinator I started by converting my solution for Sudoku Solver but that was timing out for everything except the first test/validator.
Adapting my solution for Killer Sudoku Extreme Challenge (the puzzle from Timinator) yield better results, I was not able to re-use all the optimizations due to memory limit (grid is way bigger here).
I'm nowhere near the timings of yoch, my slowest one is Test 3 with ~0.9s but I'm not using DLX and I'm using a slow language (PHP)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: About a year ago, a post by @5DN1L introduced me to Algorithm X. Over the last 9+ months, I developed an Algorithm X Solver and I worked several of the puzzles @5DN1L had identified as Algorithm X candidates. My Algorithm X Solver did the job, but it was sometimes a bit slow and I always thought I would someday need to swap out my "relatively" slow engine for the supposedly super fast DLX. Well, this puzzle forced my hand.

Sudoku is well understood. In this puzzle, the grid is just bigger. The author has done a great job with the test cases. I don't mean to put words in the author's mouth, but I get the feeling the author is suggesting we all learn DLX. Looking back over the last few days, I'm certainly glad I did.

Just a couple of housekeeping issues:

- please remove the space between grid and !

- change "Simply backtrack" to "Simple backtracking

- should "revealed cells" actually be "unrevealed cells"?

- I'd like you to add "Algorithm X" to your tags. DLX is an implementation of Algorithm X. We must understand the algorithm to understand the implementation.

For other reviewers, I'd like to know how easily you can convert your solution for the original Sudoku Solver to solve this proposed 25x25 puzzle:

https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/sudoku-solver

I spent last fall developing a non-DLX Algorithm X solver. I just took my code from Sudoku Solver and I replaced all my 9s with 25 and all my 3s with 5. I converted the input grid to numbers between 0 and 24 instead of letters so I would hopefully not have to change any other code. Overall, this all took me about 10 minutes, mostly because I had to hunt for my most recent Algorithm X Solver version.

My Algorithm X solver (Python) is nowhere near as fast as DLX and my slowest time on any test case here is about 160 ms.

I'm not against this puzzle being approved. However, I want to see what other reviewers have to say. Two things could have just happened.

1) Maybe I just demonstrated how powerful a reusable Algorithm X framework can be.

2) Maybe it's really easy to take Sudoku Solver code and modify it for this puzzle.

Here's another thought. Might you want the grids to be a bit more sparse? I fully expected my slowish Python Algorithm X Solver to take several seconds instead of 160 ms.

All sections
* All the quotation marks around the constants may be removed.

Input & Output sections
* Please change "chars" to "characters".

Constraints section
* Please move all the constraints to Goal section - they are the rules of the puzzle, not constraints on the cases.

* Is there a unique solution for each case (instead of multiple possible solutions)? If so, please state it as a constraint.

Thanks.
Thanks you for these remarks, it's clearer now.

What I can say is that the common approach to solve sudoku grids will not work here.

With regard to sparsity, I can make the grids a bit more sparse (or propose 36x36 grids), but this could be a lot harder to solve.

I've updated the statement.

I also updated the second puzzle (easier) with 16x16 grids which are solvable with a good backtracking: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/574025b92ad066c6a70e2754f4b0a786da80b
That’s awesome that you were able to do it without DLX. I did not expect to hear that!

So feel free to try it and approve it ;)
There is also an easier version here: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/574025b92ad066c6a70e2754f4b0a786da80b
I'm also very impressed because the problem is far from easy to solve. Glad to hear that it is possible to solve it in another way than DLX.

Fair enough. I just took two other random solutions from Sudoku Solver and tried to retrofit them.  Each one timed out on all test cases.

FYI: My original solution, prior to Algorithm X, also works just fine. I think the difference will be in whether or not the algorithm attempts any grid optimization at all vs pure brute force backtracking start to finish.

It looks like you made test 5 and validator 5 significantly harder. I can solve the first 4 test cases and the first 4 validators with only logic, no backtracking at all. For test case 5, I believe there are still 253 unknown cells after all logic is initially applied. That is a really big jump all at once.

I am using traditional backtracking in combination with a bunch of logic and I am very close to success on test case 5 and validator 5. My Algorithm X implementation is way too slow.

I think you might have to adjust the test cases a bit more depending on what you want for your puzzle. Right now there is a giant leap from the first 4 test cases to the last. If you want to finish with a test case as tough as case 5, you might want to see if you can get the test cases to smooth out the journey from test case 1 to test case 5, maybe by making 3 and 4 a bit more difficult.

I get it that jumping straight to DLX is probably the best way to go, but do you want the non-DLX puzzler to have a reasonable chance of success? If you do, I'm not against you making test 5 a bit closer to the rest of the cases. If you're looking for primarily DLX solutions, that is fine too.

I'm also not against you going back to the original test 5 and validator 5. I ended up testing 8 random solutions from Sudoku Solver and only 1 of the 8 could pass test cases 1 to 4, so there is obviously a challenge there.

I apologize for being wishy-washy about this. There are some pretty interesting design choices to think about with your test cases depending on the audience you hope to engage. Because your solution is DLX, I'm sure it flies through everything, but a lot of non DLXers might attempt your puzzle.

I don't have a grid generator that can adapt the grid level, I only randomly remove cells as long as the solution remains unique. This way, the grids tends to be difficult.

With regard to the rating I proceed empirically by checking how long my DLX solver takes on each grid. Some can be so difficult that it doesn't finish in the given time...

I understand that there is a large gap between the different tests, I have to find a way to classify better. Maybe the number of backtracking performed by a DLX solver is a good indicator here.

I am working on DLX right now. However, if I could answer this one question, I could solve test case five, and validator five without any sort of algorithm X implementation. The question is: when trying numbers for an unknown cell, is there a way to prioritize which numbers to try first?

Any ideas?

OK, I modified the tests and validators to be more progressive, only test1, validator 1 and validator 5 remains the same.

To evaluate the level of each grid, I simply count the number of recursive calls made by my DLX solver, as an indicator of the amount of backtracking needed to solve the grid.

Here is what we have now:

TESTS
1)   626 calls, 0m0.009s
2)  1393 calls, 0m0.008s
3) 13899 calls, 0m0.044s
4) 18660 calls, 0m0.045s
5) 30315 calls, 0m0.073s

VALIDATORS
1)   626 calls, 0m0.009s
2)  2251 calls, 0m0.010s
3) 17661 calls, 0m0.048s
4) 24557 calls, 0m0.071s
5) 31537 calls, 0m0.092s

I have harder cases as well, but I see no good reason to add them.

Thank you for your remarks !

I implemented DLX. It's a lot faster than my old algorithm. Still, my DLX implementation is making over 46,000 calls to solve() just on test case 2, so I must be missing something. My DLX is timing out somewhere between 40,000 and 50,000 calls to solve() on most of the test cases and validators.

Maybe this can helps you. When I implemented DLX for sudoku, I noticed that having more constraints was beneficial. This is why unlike D. Knuth, I add a constraint (4 headers in fact) even for non-empty boxes. I have observed that this is beneficial for performance (approximately divided the time by two).

I can solve all test cases and all validators now, but I'm not sure I'm happy about it. I even get all the exact same numbers of calls to solve() as you on every test case and every validator.

By the way, I'm using Python and many of the test cases and validators are roughly 50% to 80% the time limit.

Here's my problem. All I did was flip my Matrix A vertically and horizontally. Algorithm X has a couple of non-deterministic steps and these flips affect both of those steps. The steps are:

1) When choosing a column, how are ties broken? You and I are both breaking ties simply by going left to right in Matrix A.

2) When more than one row will cover the chosen column, you and I are both simply going from top to bottom in Matrix A.

If you have some reason for why you chose that particular orientation of Matrix A, I'd like to hear it. This is not something I've run into with Algorithm X before. I can easily change my orientation now since I have the code written both ways. In the future, I guess this is a technique I try.

Still, I'd hate to be the the Codingamer that wrote a great DLX implementation, but drove himself or herself crazy all due to the wrong Matrix A orientation. Maybe this is a known technique with Algorithm X that I just don't know about. Did you run into this issue?

Not sure that I understand what you've flipped. Is it simply the clauses order, or perhaps the traversal order ?

As far as I know, there is no traversal  order that is better than another. With regard to breaking ties to select the best header, a common approach is to randomize this choice, but using the first or the last one is also considered a decent choice.

Matrix A

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knuth%27s_Algorithm_X

In the Wikipedia example, the columns are 1 to 7 from left to right and the rows are A to F from top to bottom. I changed the columns to go from 7 to 1 and I changed the rows to go from F to A.

I checked a variant of my implementation which break ties by using the last candidate, and it turns out that this way is a terrible idea for every grids I tested.

It's like that the first headers (in my case Row-Column Constraints, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exact_cover#Sudoku) are better choices to cover than others, but I don't know why.

This Wikipedia entry mentions: "A Sudoku can be constructed to work against backtracking. Assuming the solver works from top to bottom (as in the animation), a puzzle with few clues (17), no clues in the top row, and has a solution "987654321" for the first row, would work in opposition to the algorithm." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudoku_solving_algorithms#Backtracking

I think this should be taken into consideration when designing the test cases (in general; I'm not commenting on whether the coverage of the current tests and validators are adequate or not).

This is only true for "naive" backtracking approaches, which won't work here anyway because the problem is far too difficult to solve that way. As soon as heuristics are used to choose the variables on which to try first, this problem no longer arises.

I think the test cases are fine as is. I have used plenty of heuristics with Algorithm X before, but I always had a reason for doing so. I’m still stumped as to why prioritizing the row-col constraints over other constraints leads quicker solutions. (and I am upset that I am just now figuring this out after about 18 Algorithm X puzzles, but that is on me) My guess is that there is no reason and that grids could be designed that preferred some other prioritization technique.

I just want to make sure of one thing. The way things are today, this puzzle is way harder than your original submission. I am ready to approve. I just want to make sure this is what you want. There are things to be learned from both versions, and each version really would have a different audience.

What about two identical puzzles, a part one and part two? Obviously, the test cases would be different, but other than that, just a short explanation as to why there is part I and part II. If you were to do that, test case five should be a little easier on part one so that it also could be solved with just logic like the original four test cases were. Part II would be today’s version that almost certainly will require DLX.

Part I would only be medium. Part II would definitely be hard. And you get credit for two puzzles!

I think there is definitely a room to create an easier first part, but I believe it would be preferable to use 16x16 grids for that. These grids can already be pretty challenging for "basic" solvers, but they are much more approachable and probably don't require a DLX approach.

In any case, the problem in its current version is suitable for me. The only thing I'm hesitant about is whether it should be marked as expert instead of hard.

Regarding the question about the functioning of the DLX algorithm for sudokus and the preference for Row-Col headers, I don't have any answer. However, I can say that the provided grids are randomly generated using a SAT solver that is completely different from my DLX solver (and much more efficient). Therefore, I don't think the grids are biased in any particular way.

I made a 16x16 sudoku puzzle, you can check it here : https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/574025b92ad066c6a70e2754f4b0a786da80b

it turns out that some cases aren't much easier than 25x25, I picked the "easy" and "medium" ones, but you can check this one for instance :

H..C.JD.....KA..
..D.O.E...P.B...
...LA....J..C.DM
...O.GL.....JN.H
I........F.PD.H.
.AMDF...N.....J.
....B..N..G.AE.C
..H.KI...C.E.BMN
.BG..H..J...O..I
E....BC...OI....
...IJ.OML.KB..E.
..PM.....G......
..CA...E.NM..O..
...E...G..LJ..IP
....P...E...HGC.
..O.M.K.I..C..BA

>> I believe it would be preferable to use 16x16 grids for that

Grid size does not necessarily determine difficulty. We could easily create a 16x16 grid that would be much more difficult to solve than a 36x36 grid. I believe grid composition has a larger role in difficulty than size.

Whatever you decide, if you submit a medium version of this puzzle, I would give it a rave review as long as it truly targets the medium puzzler by emphasizing:

1) Traditional backtracking alone will not be enough.
2) Using logic to make your backtracking more efficient is the key.
3) In fact, each of these grids can be solved 100% with logic if you choose to go that route.
4) Algorithm X / DLX can be used to solve these grids, but they are definitely not necessary.

Also, if you create a medium version of this puzzle, I think you should publish a non DLX, non Algorithm X solution. In my mind, the purpose of a medium version of the puzzle is to engage the puzzler in the concept of using logic to increase backtracking efficiency. As you mentioned above, designing the puzzle to almost certainly require DLX makes it hard, if not expert.

One last comment on a medium version of this puzzle. Just my opinion, but I believe a bunch of the authors of the Sudoku solutions I tried to retrofit would do the medium version, but many less will do this hard version. To me, that justifies having both versions.
I think traditional backtracking alone SHOULD be enough for a medium puzzle. Optimisation is more for hard and expert difficulty levels.

I respectfully disagree. Java Coffee Cup's Cylinders comes to mind off the top of my head as a medium level puzzle that required optimization. I used optimization on all three of these medium grid problems:

Suguru Solver
Futoshiki Solver
Shikaku Solver

To be fair, I would need to check on these three to see if they were actually solvable strictly with brute force and no logic at all. Maybe I just did extra work.

The medium level Sudoku puzzles I'm suggesting don't require very fancy logic. They just won't be fast enough with standalone brute force backtracking. The backtracking needs to be just a tiny bit smart about which paths to try first and which paths have been eliminated. This technique is nowhere near the difficulty level of implementing Algorithm X.

@Timinator: 
I agree, it is the composition of the grid that is important to determine the level of a grid. I thought 16x16 was small enough to be affordable anyway, but it turns out that's not true.

About the level definition, I think that only simple heuristics (e.g. taking the most constrained variable) can be considered "medium".

So I'll keep this hard version of 25x25 for now, and going to think about a simpler version which involve something more interesting than naive approach.

Got it. I put some housekeeping issues in a new post. As soon as those are addressed, I have no more comments on this submission.

Just to reiterate, I think your original first 4 test cases from way back on Day 1 were perfect medium level puzzles. Secondly, to be medium, all test cases on a new submission must be possible to solve WITHOUT Algorithm X or DLX.

I agree with yoch's comment on level definition.

@Timinator: Applying your definition will mean that there is a big gap between easy and medium. There are some puzzles whose difficulty levels are not classified appropriately, because:
(1) Initially community puzzles were not classified by difficulty. When CG initially started such classification, they used some kind of algorithm to start off, and that algorithm had resulted in weird classification for some puzzles.
(2) Puzzles that are created afterwards may not always be classified appropriately either.

>> taking the most constrained variable

I think we're all on the same page actually. I consider this statement to be optimization compared to pure brute force backtracking. Either way, I also completely agree with yoch's comment.

@5DN1L - @yoch now has a 16x16 puzzle submission that we both feel good about. I'd love to have your discerning eye give it a look. Our goal is to create a Sudoku puzzle that is truly between the relatively easy level of the original Sudoku Solver and the very difficult level of this 25x25. Your opinion on how well we met or did not meet that goal would also be valuable and much appreciated!
I checked it in 2 different ways (DLX and SAT solvers), but I'd be happy to have an outside confirmation.

@5DN1L - check out my most recent comments on this contribution. I've never run into this with Algorithm X. Have you?

At least I finally took the time to swap out my Algorithm X engine with DLX. I need to transpose and flip Matrix A with my original engine to really do a comparison.

With a bare minimum of logical deductions to reduce the initial search space, the times taken to solve using my Algorithm X solver (Python) locally on my laptop were as follows (the performance was quite wild):

Test 1: 0.02 s
Validator 1: 0.01 s
Test 2: 48 s
Validator 2: 13 s (0.96 s*)
Test 3: 6 s
Validator 3: 105 s
Test 4: 80 s (52 s*)
Validator 4: 4 s (1.38 s*)
Test 5: 4999 s (!) (1870 s*)
Validator 5: 44 s

* My "Algorithm X with secondary columns" solver worked better here.

I haven't done a lot of modifications to get the above results, but it does seem to show that it is not straight-forward to convert previous solutions to fit this puzzle. Maybe coders using faster languages have a different conclusion.

My previous experience in solving the harder CG puzzles with my said solver is that it can handle them but only if I have reduced the initial search space a lot first. I guess I may be able to do the same thing with this 25x25 Sudoku puzzle without switching to DLX or another approach, but I'm not sure.
